title: Executive-centered AI? Designing predictive systems for the public sector
theoretical_background: Public value theory; Socio-technical systems theory
research_description: The article explores how AI is designed and implemented in the public sector through two case studies in healthcare and accounting. It critiques the human-centered AI narrative by showing how AI systems are being developed primarily for managerial efficiency, rather than enhancing human labor.
research_results: The study reveals that AI systems are designed for cost-efficiency and top-down implementation, benefitting managers rather than frontline workers. It questions the ideal of human-centered AI and suggests that more effort is needed to rethink human-machine relationships in the context of public governance.
future_research: Future studies should focus on reconceptualizing human-machine partnerships, especially in the context of AI governance and the ethical implications of automating public sector functions.
